description: Agricultural settlement initially focused around a double enclosure. During the 3rd to 4th CE a rectangular building with stone foundations was constructed, it has been interpreted as a cottage style building. Based on pottery evidence the building continued to be used until the mid or late 4th CE with some coin finds from later periods. Based on the distribution of coins within the cottage, a domestic shrine has been suggested.
bibliography: “A435 Norton Lenchwick Bypass Excavations in the Arrow Valley. Interim Report and Post-Excavation Proposal,” 1994. https://doi.org/10.5284/1024153.
Martyn, Blick, Brindle, and et al. “Salford Priors, Areas C1, C2 and C3 (Warwickshire).” The Rural Settlement of Roman Britain: an online resource, 2015. https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449.
Palmer. “Archaeological Excavations in the Arrow Valley, Warwickshire.” Birmingham and Warwickshire Archaeological Society Transaction 103 (1999).
